dataset.title: Long Term Aquatic Monitoring Program (LTAM) Cross Section Surveys and Data Analysis, 2006-2017, in support of the Cedar River Watershed Habitat Conservation Plan for City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities, in King County, WA

abstract.para: This package contains site verification data for the Long Term Aquatic Monitoring (LTAM) program, in support of the Cedar River Watershed Habitat Conservation Plan for City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities, in King County, WA. A level survey was conducted at each of the (3) cross sections for all (25) monitoring sites for 2006-2017, Cleaned raw data, summarized data, and graphs are included in the package.

Significant stream features were surveyed such as bankfull edge, wetted edge, and floodplain using an optical level on a tripod. The focus of the survey was to get detailed information near and under bankfull elevation, with fewer data points outside of bankfull and served only as confirmation of bankfull. The analysis included confirming bankfull elevation by interpreting the cross section graph, reading the surveyor notes, and reviewing photos. Totals and averages were calculated for cross sectional area, bankfull depth and width, and width to depth ratio for each cross section and then averaged for each site.
For more detailed information on the LTAM program, refer to the LTAM Methods and Reports package.

intellectualRights.para: This information is released under the Creative Commons license - Attribution - CC BY (https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by/4.0/). The consumer of these data ("Data User" herein) is required to cite it appropriately in any publication that results from its use. The Data User should realize that these data may be actively used by others for ongoing research and that coordination may be necessary to prevent duplicate publication. The Data User is urged to contact the authors of these data if any questions about methodology or results occur. Where appropriate, the Data User is encouraged to consider collaboration or co-authorship with the authors. The Data User should realize that misinterpretation of data may occur if used out of context of the original study. While substantial efforts are made to ensure the accuracy of data and associated documentation, complete accuracy of data sets cannot be guaranteed. All data are made available "as is." The Data User should be aware, however, that data are updated periodically and it is the responsibility of the Data User to check for new versions of the data. The data authors and the repository where these data were obtained shall not be liable for damages resulting from any use or misinterpretation of the data. Thank you.

description.para: Update yearly if additional data is collected.

contact.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

description.para: Cross section end points were established during the first monitoring year and consisted of pounding in rebar at least 25 feet away from bankfull edge and at approximately the same elevation on both the right and left banks. The same cross section was surveyed in subsequent monitoring years. Occasionally a rebar was damaged or missing, and if so, they were re-established using information from the Permanent Reference survey such that the elevation of the new rebar could always be related to the elevation of the old rebar.

A fiberglass reel tape was attached from right bank rebar to left bank rebar (where right and left banks refer to the stream bank when facing downstream) such that the zero end of the tape was always at the right bank.

The survey started and ended on a stable point, usually the top of right bank rebar. Doing so “closed the survey loop” and ensured that accuracy could be calculated. If the accuracy was more than +/- 0.25 feet, the survey was re-done. Re-doing a survey only happened a few times over the course of the 12 year study.

One observer used a level attached to a tripod to measure readings on a stadia rod held by another observer in the stream. The observer in the stream captured significant features such as floodplain, bankfull edge, wetted with, thalweg, woody debris, terrace, and permanent vegetation line. The focus of the survey was to get detailed information near and under bankfull elevation, with fewer data points outside of bankfull and served only as confirmation of bankfull.

The data was reviewed for completeness and errors and graphed in Excel. Obvious data outliers were removed from analysis. Bankfull elevation was confirmed by interpreting the graphs, considering the surveyor notes, and reviewing photos. Totals and averages were calculated for cross sectional area, bankfull depth and width, and width to depth ratio for each cross section and then averaged for each site for a particular survey year.

personnel.organizationName: City of Seattle, Seattle Public Utilities

abstract.para: Long Term Aquatic Monitoring (LTAM) pebble count summary data and individual working data, 2006-2017, in support of the Cedar River Watershed Habitat Conservation Plan, for Seattle Public Utilities in North Bend, Washington. Field methods were based on Wolman Pebble Count methods, e.g. using the blind touch method off the tip of the boot and measuring intermediate b-axis for at least 100 particles, bankfull to bankfull, for all channels at a particular cross section. Data is summarized for each cross section for each year at each site, as well as all cross sections for each year at each site, into particle size class distribution classes and noting p-value significance.

dataTable.entityDescription: Cross section level survey data for each of the (3) cross sections at all (25) monitoring sites for 2006-2017. Includes cross sectional area results between each survey point that is below a specified bankfull elevation.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Main Sorting No, a number that is used to order records for the purposes of loading data, grouping data, or building formulas.
Method, an abbreviation or acronym whereas the method is a group of methods for a project or program and is described in a separate document.

Year Site ID, a number that is used to group data and is a conjugate of the 4 digit Sample Year and Site No. For example, 20062 refers to Sample Year 2006, Site 2, and 201022 refers to Sample Year 2010, Site 22. If the analysis is a Enter "999" for
User Name, as downloaded from Pendragon Forms or other electronic form. Also, "999" refers to not applicable; and "-999" refers to data that is required but is missing.
Timestamp, Date or Date and Time for when the data was collected and in format MM/DD/YYY hh:mm:ss.
Distance on Tape, as noted on the drag tape, and if a Profile Pool survey exists, matches the Distance on Tape from the pool head record from the Profile Pool survey. Units in feet.

Cumulative Distance, where the survey starts with an arbitrary number (usually zero). Thereafter, if the location is NOT a tape change, then Formula is (Cumulative Distance = previous Cumulative Dist + current Dist on Tape - previous Dist on Tape). If the location is a tape change, then Formula is (Cumulative Distance = previous Cumulative Dist + current Dist on Tape - Dist on New Tape). Units in feet.
New Tape Distance, If the location is at a tape change, the distance noted on the new tape, to the nearest tenth foot; if not at a tape change, enter “999”. Units in feet.
Wetted Edge Water Depth, if the location is at a wetted edge, measure the water depth with a stadia rod, to the nearest half-tenth foot; if not at a wetted edge, enter “999”. Units in feet.

Stadia Height Type, whereas “Foresight” is when the station has not moved from the previous shot; “Backsight” is either the first shot of the survey or the first shot after the station has moved out of order; and “Turning point” is the first shot after the station has moved in order.
Backsight Height, the stadia height reading for the very first shot of the survey or when the station has moved out of order. Units in feet.
Instrument Height, Formula is (Instrument Height = previous Instrument Ht + current Backsight or Turning Pt - previous Foresight). Units in feet.
Foresight Height, the stadia height reading when the level station has NOT moved from the previous reading. Units in feet.
Turning Point Height, the stadia height reading for the first shot after the station has moved in order. Units in feet.
Elevation, of the surveyed point. Formula is (Elevation = Station height - Foresight or Turning point or Backsight). Units in feet.

Wooden Stake No., The number associated with a Turning point wooden stake. If the Turning point was not made on a wooden stake, then remark on the feature in which the Turning point occurred, ie "rock", "lwd", etc.

BANKFULL HELPER - Bankfull Order, The order in which the Bankfull formulas will run. Certain records are excluded from Bankfull such as tributaries not in Bankfull, stakes, rebar, etc and are noted with 999. The order must start at 1 and increment by 1 thereafter - there cannot be any gaps in the order with the exception of 999. There also cannot be any duplicates with the exception of 999.

Bankfull Elevation Manual Input, A professional hydrologist's determination of the most appropriate bankfull elevation for the cross section, after reviewing the cross section graph and data (including phrases and comments) and considering other geomorphic characteristics. Units in feet.
Baseline Survey Elevation, the elevation in which to compare to other surveys. If the survey point Elevation is not to be compared to another survey, enter "999". Units in feet.

Baseline Survey Year, the sample year in which the surveyed location (typically a benchmark) is the basis for comparison for the same surveyed location in other sample years. The other sample years can be before or after the baseline survey year. If the location is not compared to another survey, enter "999". Loaded as 4 digit number and not a date format.

Elevation Difference From Baseline, for benchmarks or other features in which the elevation to a different survey is to be compared, Formula is = Baseline Survey Elevation - Elevation. If the survey point Elevation is not to be compared to another survey, enter "999". Units in feet.
Phrases are comments that we often make during surveys. Phrases are an extension of comments. Phrases are not meant to be domains and can change based on a users preference.
Comments, free form text for interesting or unusual sightings, problems, or issues.
Cross Section No., A number that identifies the cross section, whereas the cross sections are typically (but not always) numbered sequentially starting from the most downstream end of the site.
Site No, a number that has been assigned to the site, whereas the same site number is used for repeat surveys.
Stream Name (short), the abbreviated or shortened stream name of the site that is being surveyed.
The names or initials of each person who participated in the survey.

Cumulative Distance Start, The survey starts with an arbitrary number (usually zero). Thereafter, if the location is NOT a tape change, then (Cumulative Distance = previous Cumulative Dist + current Dist on Tape - previous Dist on Tape); if the location is a tape change, then (Cumulative Distance = previous Cumulative Dist + current Dist on Tape - Dist on New Tape). Units in feet.
Backsight Elevation Start, The Elevation that starts the survey or a new section within the same survey (ie. Backsight). Units in feet.
HELPER - Copy New Tape Distance, The most recent or current New Tape Distance. Units in feet.

HELPER - Instrument Height Order, The order in which the Instrument Height formulas will run. Either manual entry or derived from Timestamp, if Timestamp is unique (requires hh:mm:ss). The order must start at 1 and increment by 1 thereafter - there cannot be any gaps in sequencing or duplicates.

HELPER - Cumulative Distance Order, The order in which the Cumulative Distance formulas will run. Certain records are excluded from Cumulative Distance formulas such as Turning points and stakes, which are noted with 999. There cannot be any duplicates with the exception of 999. Units in feet.

BANKFULL HELPER - Copy Next Cumulative Distance, A helper field to that is used to assist in calculating Bankfull Width and Area. The Bankfull formulas can be written without a helper field however the formulas are extremely long and the excel worksheet suffers from a performance lag. The helper field keeps the Bankfull formulas simple and easy to understand. Formula is =IFERROR(INDEX($F$16:$F$5000,MATCH(1,INDEX((P16+1=$P$16:$P$5000)*(B16=$B$16:$B$5000),),0)),999), whereas Column F is Cumulative Distance; Column P is Bankfull Order; and Column B is Year Site Identifier. Units in feet.

BANKFULL HELPER - Copy Next Elevation, A helper field to that is used to assist in calculating Bankfull Width Depth and Area. The Bankfull formulas can be written without a helper field however the formulas are extremely long and the excel worksheet suffers from a performance lag. The helper field keeps the Bankfull formulas simple and easy to understand. Formula is =IFERROR(INDEX($N$16:$N$5000,MATCH(1,INDEX((P16+1=$P$16:$P$5000)*(B16=$B$16:$B$5000),),0)),999), whereas Column N is Elevation; Column P is Bankfull Order; and Column B is Year Site Identifier. Units in feet.

Bankfull Section Width via COMPLEX Formula, A calculated bankfull width for a surveyed point in a cross section. Uses Bankfull Elevation and the Elevation of the surveyed point. Section width is averaged when one point is w/in bankfull and one point is out of bankfull. Formula is =ABS(IF(AG16=999,0,IF(N16<Q16,IF(AH16<Q16,(AG16-F16),(Q16-N16)*(AG16-F16)/(AH16-N16)),IF(AH16<Q16,(Q16-AH16)*(AG16-F16)/(N16-AH16),0)))), whereas Column AG is Copy Next Cumulative Distance; Column N is Elevation; Column Q is Bankfull Elevation; Column F is Cumulative Distance; and Column AH is Copy Next Elevation. Units in feet.

Bankfull Section Depth via COMPLEX Formula, A calculated bankfull depth for a surveyed point in a cross section. Uses Bankfull Elevation and the Elevation of the surveyed point. Section depth is averaged when one point is w/in bankfull and one point is out of bankfull. Formula is =IF(AH16=999,0,IF(N16<Q16,IF(AH16<Q16,(Q16-(N16+AH16)*0.5),(Q16-N16)*0.5),IF(AH16<Q16,(Q16-AH16)*0.5,0))), whereas Column AH is Copy Next Elevation; Column N is Elevation; and Column Q is Bankfull Elevation. Units in feet.

Bankfull Section Area via COMPLEX Formula, A calculated bankfull area for a surveyed point in a cross section. Section depth and width are averaged when one point is w/in bankfull and one point is out of bankfull. Formula is =AI16*AJ16, whereas Column AI is Bankfull Section Width and Column AJ is Bankfull Section Depth. Units in feet.

First Record Type, For the first record of the day, whereas “Turning pt (in order)” is for is for a continuation of survey already started and the feature to be surveyed is the same as the very last shot of the previous day; “Backsight (out of order)” is for a continuation of survey already started and the feature to be surveyed is not the same as the very last shot of the previous day; and “Backsight (new survey)” is for the very first shot of the survey. If the record is not first record, leave blank.

LB to RB Azimuth, The azimuth of a line, and if at a cross section survey, it is from left bank (LB) to right bank (RB), using a compass, while standing at least 10 feet from the metal rebar (because metal can skew the compass bearing); required at least once during the survey; if azimuth is not taken, enter “999”. Units in decimal degrees.

Declination East, at the time the azimuth direction was measured. It is the angle between magnetic morth (the direction a compass needle points) and true north (ie grid north or geogrpahic north pole), Declination East is a positive number when magnetic north is east of true north. Note that Declination East changes about 0.5 degrees every 3 years in the North Bend, Washington vicinity. Declination is usually set on the backside of the compas by turning a small screw that shifts a black arrow to the desired degrees setting. If declination is not set properly on a compass, all azimuth readings will be incorrect. At the beginning of the field season, all observers should set their compass to the same degrees setting to reduce error between observers. Units in decimal degrees.

dataTable.entityDescription: Summary data for cross section level surveys for each of the (3) cross sections at all (25) monitoring sites for 2006-2017. Totals, averages, and ratios for widths and depths are derived from the level survey.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Main Sorting No, a number that is used to order records for the purposes of loading data, grouping data, or building formulas.
Method, an abbreviation or acronym whereas the method is a group of methods for a project or program and is described in a separate document.

Year Site XS ID, a number that is used to group data and is a conjugate of the 4 digit Sample Year, Site No, "<DECIMAL>", and Cross Section No. For example, 20062.1 refers to Sample Year 2006, Site 2, Cross Section 1, and 201022.3 refers to Sample Year 2010, Site 22, Cross Section 3.

Year Site ID, a number that is used to group data and is a conjugate of the 4 digit Sample Year and Site No. For example, 20062 refers to Sample Year 2006, Site 2, and 201022 refers to Sample Year 2010, Site 22. If the analysis is a Enter "999" for
Site No, a number that has been assigned to the site, whereas the same site number is used for repeat surveys.
Stream Name (short), the abbreviated or shortened stream name of the site that is being surveyed.
Survey Year, the sample year of a dataset.. Loaded as 4 digit number and not a date format.
Cross Section No., A number that identifies the cross section, whereas the cross sections are typically (but not always) numbered sequentially starting from the most downstream end of the site.
Text string to group records for data analysis, for instance "XS" for cross section grouping, "XS Average" for cross section average, or "By Reach" for reach scale analysis.

Bankfull Elevation Manual Input, A professional hydrologist's determination of the most appropriate bankfull elevation for the cross section, after reviewing the cross section graph and data (including phrases and comments) and considering other geomorphic characteristics. Units in feet.

Bankfull Section Area via COMPLEX Formula, A calculated bankfull area for a surveyed point in a cross section. Section depth and width are averaged when one point is w/in bankfull and one point is out of bankfull. Formula is =AI16*AJ16, whereas Column AI is Bankfull Section Width and Column AJ is Bankfull Section Depth. Units in feet.

Width to Depth Ratio (BFW/AVE BFD), A ratio that describes the channel shape, whereas a large number indicates wide and shallow and a small number indicates narrow and deep. Formula is (Width to Depth Ratio = Bankfull Width / Average Bankfull Depth).

Measured Bankfull Width, which is the surface width of the stream at bankfull stage where the bankfull width is "measured" with some type of levelling instrument like line level, eye level or is calculated from a cross section graph, or auto-level. An unlevel rangefinder is not "measured". Bankfull stage is the water level in the stream just before the stream overtops its banks and floods. Several good indicators are needed to confirm bankfull width such as permanent vegetation, slope breaks, deposition of fines, etc. Note that water or moss lines on rocks are the least reliable indicators. Units in feet.

Average Bankfull Depth, is the average depth at bankfull elevation and includes all channels at the bankfull location. Formula is (Sum of all bankfull depth measurements / Number of bankfull depth measurements). If only several bankfull depths are measured (ie. 1/4, 1/2, and 3/4 distance from bankfull edge), one of the measurements will need to include "zero" to account for the zero depths at the bankfull edges. A more accurate measurement for Bankfull Depth is Bankfull Mean Depth, where Formula is (Bankfull cross sectional area / Bankfull width) and usually requires 20 to 30 depth measurements. Units in feet.
Max Bankfull Depth, is the max depth for all channels at the bankfull location. Units in feet.

Outside Bankfull are comments that describe which areas of the survey should be excluded from bankfull analysis. It is usually expressed as a range of distances (ie, 0-30 ft, 260-280 ft, etc) and correlates to a cross section tape that is used to measure bankfull width. Tributaries, most wetlands, and high floodplains should be excluded from bankfull analysis. Units in feet.
Problems With Data highlight issues about the dataset that could be an issue for data analysis (ie. poor bankfull indicators, not enough surveyed points, observer bias, etc)

dataTable.entityDescription: A filename inventory of the zipped folder that contains Excel cross section graph files for all (25) monitoring sites for 2006-2017. There is one Excel file per monitoring site, where each file has (3) cross section graphs, and each graph has all survey years depicted in the graph.

attribute.attributeDefinition: Main Sorting No, a number that is used to order records for the purposes of loading data, grouping data, or building formulas.
Method, an abbreviation or acronym whereas the method is a group of methods for a project or program and is described in a separate document.
Site No, a number that has been assigned to the site, whereas the same site number is used for repeat surveys.
Stream Name (short), the abbreviated or shortened stream name of the site that is being surveyed.

Filename Description, a brief and general description of the document and should be distinctively different from the filename, where the filename usually has site number, sample year, and/or location information.
Compressed Zip Folder Name, where the folder contains multiple files.
Folder Path Name, which is the subfolder path in a compressed zip folder. The zip folder name and the filename of the individual file is not included.

Filename, which is the name of file with the file extension included. It does not include any folders or subfolder names. The filename should contain descriptive information such has site number, sample year, and/or location.
File Extension Type, which is the electronic file extension type that is recognized by computers (ie. .doc, .docx, .xlsx, pdf, etc) and includes the decimal point.

Folder Path and Filename, which is a conjugate of the Folder Path Name and Filename and is the full path of the document name, with folders and subfolders, but excluding the Compressed Zip Folder Name.

otherEntity.entityDescription: An example of (3) Cross Section graphs, for xs1, xs2, and xs3 for (1) monitoring site and all survey years, where all graphs have been uploaded as Other Entities in a zipped folder.

A zipped folder that contains (25) Excel cross section graph files for each of the (25) monitoring sties for 2006-2017. Each file has (3) graphs depicting xs1, xs2, and xs3 and includes all survey years (4 or 5 years, depending on the monitoring site).

A single Excel spreadsheet that contains cross section data for all (25) monitoring sites for 2006-2007 and was used to create each of the (25) Excel cross section graph files. Major channel features such as bankfull edge, wetted width, woody debris, side channels, benchmarks, and floodplain are color coded in the data and relate to the same features depicted in the graphs.
